pullRequest.body:
Co-authored-by: Emily Riehl [eriehl@jhu.edu](mailto:eriehl@jhu.edu)
Co-authored-by: Dagur Asgeirsson [dagurtomas@gmail.com](mailto:dagurtomas@gmail.com)

---

These are the classes only, API to follow in PR #22921.

Rewrite to replace PR-stack under #20967

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [a177a10e14](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22916/commits/a177a10e1454f6e4892081e45e8ed2c752f9cf3f)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Enriched.Limits.HasConicalLimits` (new file)|632|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ HasConicalLimit`
`+ HasConicalLimits`
`+ HasConicalLimitsOfShape`
`+ HasConicalLimitsOfSize`
`+ eCoyoneda`
`+ instHasLimitsOfShape`
`+ instHasLimitsOfSize`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
I would prefer `V` not being an `outParam` (a feature which is essentially not used at all in the category theory API).
Could you give an example where the instance inference would not work without the `outParam`?

For example, if `V` is not an `outParam` the following error appears almost everywhere where one tries to define an instance, in this PR: `instHasLimitsOfShape` and `instHasLimitsOfSize`

Example error message:

```lean
/-
error: cannot find synthesization order for instance @instHasLimitsOfShape with type
   {J : Type u} [inst : Category.{v, u} J] (V : Type u') [inst_1 : Category.{v', u'} V]
    [inst_2 : MonoidalCategory V] (C : Type u) [inst_3 : Category.{v, u} C] 
    [inst_4 : EnrichedOrdinaryCategory V C]
    [inst_5 : HasConicalLimitsOfShape J V C], HasLimitsOfShape J C
all remaining arguments have metavariables:
  Category.{v', u'} ?V
  @MonoidalCategory ?V ?inst
  @EnrichedOrdinaryCategory ?V ?inst ?inst C inst
  @HasConicalLimitsOfShape J inst ?V ?inst ?inst C inst ?inst
-/
instance {J : Type u}
    [inst : Category.{v, u} J]
    (V : Type u') [Category.{v', u'} V] [MonoidalCategory V]
    (C : Type u) [Category.{v, u} C] [EnrichedOrdinaryCategory V C]
    [inst_5 : HasConicalLimitsOfShape J V C] :
    HasLimitsOfShape J C where
  has_limit _ := inferInstance
```

(the error is not present if `def xy` is written instead of `instance`).
I'm open to other fixes, but `outParam` was the (only) way I knew to tell Lean that it should find `V` delayed.

Is there a reason `outParam` is not used in category theory or is there a good alternative? To my understanding `V` has a bit a unique role which might not be encountered that often otherwise in the category theory api: really the presence of `MonoidalCategory V` should uniquely determine which `V` to use. Reading the docstring of `outParam` I got the impression this is exactly what it is used for, isn't it?

I do not think that `V` is uniquely determined. For example, if `C` is a category of functors to `SSet`, we may use `V := SSet` or `C`.
Let us keep the `outParam` for now.

Could you add lemmas saying that `HasConicalLimit(sOfShape/...)` imply the corresponding `HasLimit(...)`?
(I am not sure we can make it instances though?)

Copied them from the follow-up PR :+1:

I added the once as `example` which are already found by `inferInstance`.

These blocks are not super-reabable, could write these in a more compact way as:
```
instance [HasConicalLimitsOfShape J V C] : HasLimitsOfShape J C where
  has_limit _ := inferInstance
```

pullRequest.title: feat(CategoryTheory/Enriched/Limits): Add conical limits for enriched ordinary categories
